Research Paper Mesoporous CuOx/VOx derived from amorphous MOFs as a highly selective catalyst for aerobic oxidation of alcohols to aldehydes Zhigang Zhang Writing – original draft Resources Methodology Investigation Formal analysis Data curation Shuai Wang Validation Investigation Formal analysis Wenwen Li Formal analysis Data curation Yuntao Hu Validation Data curation Bin Wang Writing – review & editing Writing – original draft Formal analysis ⁎ Gengxiu Zheng Writing – review & editing Supervision Huaiqing Zhao Writing – review & editing Writing – original draft Supervision Project administration Methodology Funding acquisition Conceptualization ⁎ School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, University of Jinan, Jinan 250022, PR China School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering University of Jinan Jinan 250022 PR China School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, University of Jinan, Jinan 250022, PR China ⁎ Corresponding authors. The selective oxidation of alcohols to aldehydes using oxygen as the sole oxidant under mild conditions presents a scientifically challenging task. Here, the bimetallic CuOx/VOx composite as a heterogenous catalyst was synthesized through the partial deligandation of amorphous MOFs (aMOFs) for the selective oxidation of alcohols to aldehydes with base-free condition with molecular oxygen as the oxidant at 80 °C. The catalyst was characterized by XRD, TEM, SEM, HRTEM, BET, XPS, Raman, and FTIR spectroscopy. The characteristic results and mechanism experiments reveal that the synergistic effect between CuOX and VOX via Cu-O-V bonds and the presence of abundant oxygen vacancies on the surface of the material are crucial for the efficient catalytic oxidation of the alcohols. Importantly, the role of nitrogen atoms in the catalyst, both as an electron-donor and a basicity-enhancer, significantly improves the catalytic performance of CuOx/VOx. Mechanistic studies indicate that the reaction primarily involves a free radical process and the formation of H2O2 in situ. The catalytic system exhibits a broad substrate scope and excellent selectivity. The catalyst recycling experiments show that its catalytic performance remained robust, with no significant loss in the catalytic activity observed. Graphical abstract Mesoporous CuOx/VOx derived from amorphous MOFs as a heterogenous catalyst enables the selective oxidation of alcohols to aldehydes with additive-free using oxygen as the sole oxidant under mild conditions. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Bimetallic synergistic Amorphous MOFs-derivatives Metallic oxides Partial deligandation Aerobic oxidation Data availability The data that support the findings of this study are available from the corresponding author upon reasonable request. 1 Introduction As one of the most important chemicals in organic synthesis, aldehydes serve as powerful building blocks for assembling diverse molecular structures, which are widely used in the pharmaceutical synthesis and fine chemicals industry [1]. And selective oxidation of alcohols to aldehydes represents one of the most efficient synthetic approaches [2]. Traditional oxidants such as potassium permanganate, manganese dioxide, pyridinium chlorochromate, pyridinium dichromate, and Jones reagent are usually used for the oxidation of alcohol to aldehyde [3]. Nevertheless, these systems often suffer from low efficiency and the generation of toxic byproducts. In recent decades, oxygen as an green oxidant has garnered widespread attention due to its environmental friendliness and zero-pollution nature [4]. Some important efforts have been made in the selective oxidation of alcohols to aldehydes with oxygen as the oxidant in both homogeneous [5,6] and heterogeneous catalytic systems [7,8]. Considering the challenges of catalyst separation and recovery in homogeneous catalytic systems, the recyclability of heterogeneous catalysts has attracted significant attention. Unfortunately, the aerobic oxidation of alcohols to aldehydes in heterogeneous catalytic systems often requires extra additives and harsh reaction conditions [9–12]. Therefore, the development of catalysts for the selective aerobic oxidation of alcohols to aldehydes without additives under mild conditions remains a significant challenge in heterogeneous catalytic systems. Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), known for their high surface area, tunable pore size, surface functionality, and topological properties, are widely recognized as promising candidates for catalytic engineering [13–16]. And metal oxides derived from the well-defined MOFs have wide applications in catalytic oxidation using oxygen or other oxidants [17–21]. However, the well-defined crystalline structures of these materials often limit the coordination of unsaturated sites and active adsorption centers on the catalyst surface [22]. In contrast, amorphous MOFs and their derivatives can create more defects and unsaturated coordination sites on their surfaces due to their non-periodic atomic arrangements [23]. Additionally, motivated by the concept of "quasi-MOFs", the partial deligandation strategy has been adopted for constructing structural defects and introducing hierarchical micro- and mesopores [24]. Recently, Cu-nanowire@quasi-MOF through the pyrolysis of a Cu/Co bimetal-MOFs can be applied for the selective oxidation of alcohols to aldehydes [25]. Therefore, amorphous MOFs derivatives obtained via a partial deligandation strategy, rich in abundant oxygen vacancies and catalytic active sites, provide a promising heterogenous catalyst for the aerobic oxidation of alcohols. In this work, CuOx/VOx was obtained through the partial deligandation of amorphous MOFs (Fig. 1 ), which was employed as a catalyst for the selective alcohol oxidation under mild conditions without extra additives with molecular oxygen as the sole oxidant. And the catalyst can be reused for five times without significant loss of catalytic activity. The excellent performance of the catalyst could be attributed to the abundant oxygen vacancies on the surface of the catalyst, which facilitate oxygen adsorption toward the generation of H2O2, leading to the formation of the desired product with high selectivity. Moreover, the synergistic effect between CuOX and VOX via Cu-O-V bonds and alkaline enhancement of nitrogen species in the catalyst are also essential for the catalytic oxidation of alcohols [26]. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Materials Copper (II) nitrate trihydrate (Cu(NO3)2·3H2O), vanadium oxysulfate hydrate (VOSO4·xH2O), and 2,2′- bipyridine-5,5′- dicarboxylic acid (H2Bpydc) were purchased from Macklin Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd. N, N-dimethylformamide (DMF), methanol (MeOH) and acetonitrile (MeCN) were purchased from Tianjin Fuyu Fine Chemical Co., Ltd. in China. All reagents are analytical grade and without purification before use. 2.2 Synthesis of Cu(NO3)2@V-Bpydc VOSO4·xH2O (1.81 g) and H2Bpydc (3.66 g) were added to a round bottom flask containing 250 mL DMF, and then the flask was placed in a heating module, then gradually heated to 147 °C, and the mixture was maintained at 147 °C for 16 h. After the reaction was completed, a brownish yellow solid was obtained by centrifugation, and the obtained solid was washed three times with DMF, methanol, and acetone, respectively, then activated in a vacuum oven at 120 °C for 3 h to yield V-Bpydc. Then Cu(NO3)2@V-Bpydc was prepared by the impregnation method, and V-Bpydc (100 mg) and Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (25 mg) were weighed and added into a round-bottom flask containing methanol (20 mL). Then the mixture was stirred at 50 °C for 6 h. Subsequently, the resulting suspension was concentrated with a rotary evaporator. Finally, the Cu(NO3)2@V-Bpydc was dried in an oven at 80 °C overnight. 2.3 Synthesis of catalyst and VOx The precursor of Cu(NO3)2@V-Bpydc was placed in a muffle furnace and calcined under air atmosphere. The temperature was gradually increased to the target temperature at 2.5 °C/min and kept at this temperature for several hours, yielding the final catalyst as a yellowish-brown solid powder. The catalysts are named as CuOx/VOx-M-T-H, where M (mg), T ( °C), and H (h) correspond to the Cu(NO3)2·3H2O mass, calcination temperature, and time, respectively. VOx was obtained through the calcination of V-Bpydc as the precursor in a muffle furnace under air atmosphere. The temperature was increased to 400 °C at 2.5 °C/min, and maintained at 400 °C for 5 h. 2.4 The general procedure of oxidation of benzyl alcohol Typically, 4 mg of catalyst (CuOx/VOx-25 mg- 400 °C-5 h, named as CuOx/VOx), 0.2 mmol benzyl alcohol, and 0.3 mL of MeCN were added into a 35 mL reaction tube containing a stir bar. To establish an oxygen atmosphere, the reaction tube was purged with oxygen three times. Then the reaction tube was transferred to a heat module, and the mixture was heated and stirred at 80 °C for 24 h. Upon completion of the reaction, a small aliquot of the solution was filtered through a short silica-gel column, then diluted with ethyl acetate, and analyzed by gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (GC–MS). 2.5 The general procedure of the catalyst leaching experiment Typically, 8 mg of catalyst CuOx/VOx, 0.4 mmol benzyl alcohol, and 0.6 mL of MeCN were added into a 35 mL reaction tube containing a stir bar. To establish an oxygen atmosphere, the reaction tube was purged with oxygen three times. Then the reaction tube was transferred to a heat module and stirred at 80 °C for 3 h. And then the reaction solution was transferred to a centrifuge tube, and a small aliquot of supernatant was taken for GC–MS analysis. The remaining supernatant was transferred back to the reaction tube and purged with oxygen three times. Finally, the reaction system was transferred to the heat module and heated at 80 °C for another 21 h. Upon completion of the reaction, a small aliquot of the solution was filtered, then diluted with ethyl acetate, and analyzed by gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (GC–MS). 2.6 The general procedure of catalyst recycling experiments Typically, 50 mg CuOx/VOx, 12 mmol benzyl alcohol, and 3.8 mL MeCN were added into a 150 mL reaction tube containing a stir bar. To establish an oxygen atmosphere, the reaction tube was purged with oxygen three times. The reaction tube was then transferred to a heat module, and the reaction was stirred and maintained at 80 °C for 3 h. And then the reaction solution was transferred to a centrifuge tube and the reaction tube was washed three times with methanol. The washed solution was then transferred to the centrifuge tube. The catalyst was separated using a centrifuge, and a small amount of the supernatant was taken for GC-MS analysis. The catalyst was washed three times with methanol and then dried overnight in an oven at 80 °C. Finally, the catalyst was weighed for future use. Previous studies have indicated that the stability of the catalyst should be assessed through continuous reaction cycles, and measured at a substrate conversion rate of less than 30% [27,28]. Therefore, we selected a lower conversion rate (less than 30%) within the kinetic control range for the catalyst cycling tests. The conversion of benzyl alcohol (Conv.BnOH ) and the selectivity of benzaldehyde (Sel.BzH ) were calculated using the following formulas: C o n v . B n O H ( % ) = n 0 − n B n O H n 0 × 100 % S e l . B z H ( % ) = n B z H n 0 − n B n O H × 100 % where n0 represents the initial moles of benzyl alcohol, and nBnOH and nBzH denote the final moles of benzyl alcohol and benzaldehyde, respectively. 2.6 Catalyst characterization The morphology of the catalyst was characterized by transmission electron microscopy (TEM, JEM-1400) and scanning electron microscopy (SEM, GeminiSEM360). The surface chemical properties of the catalyst were characterized using X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Thermofisher ESCALAB 250Xi). Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis was conducted using a BRUKER AXS GMBH D8 FOCUS diffractometer equipped with Cu Kα radiation. The surface area, pore size distribution, and pore volume of the samples were measured using the BET (Brunauer-Emmett-Teller) method on a Micromeritics ASAP 2460 instrument. Fourier-transform infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy was conducted using a Bruker VERTEX 70 spectrometer. The Raman spectra were analyzed by Horiba HR Evolution with a laser excitation at a wavelength of 532 nm. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was conducted with TGA55 from 30 °C to 700 °C under nitrogen atmosphere at a heating rate of 10°C /min. The UV visible absorption spectrum was obtained by testing on Shimadzu UV-2600. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 X‑ray diffraction characterization The characterizations of V-Bpydc, Cu(NO3)2@V-Bpydc and CuOx/VOx were conducted with powder X-ray diffraction (XRD), and revealed insightful details about their structural properties. aMOFs exhibit broad scattering peaks in the range of 20–30° in XRD, less crystalline MOFs may still show Bragg peaks, albeit these peaks may be broader or poorly defined [29]. Fig. 2 a shows that V-Bpydc exhibits three broad diffraction peaks at 17°, 24°, and 37°, indicating a locally ordered structure despite displaying long-range disorder [29,30]. With the introduction of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O into V-Bpydc, new diffraction peaks emerge to verify the successful synthesis of the Cu(NO3)2@V-Bpydc precursor. It is also noteworthy that the intensity of the diffraction peaks for V-Bpydc at 24.6°and 27.3°decreases after the introduction of Cu species. This suggests that Cu maybe interacts with the nitrogen atom of pyridine in V-Bpydc [31]. The XRD patterns of VOx and CuOx/VOx show absolutely difference (Fig. S1), which indicates the formation of new compounds. The presence of these new diffraction peaks is corresponded to CuO, Cu2O, and Cu, which reveals the formation of a mixture of copper vanadium oxide and Cu species. Further analysis of the composition of the new compounds in Fig. 2b suggests the presence of Cu2V2O7 and Cu0.55V2O5, with Cu2V2O7 being the predominant phase. The diffraction pattern displays characteristic peaks at 16.4°, 20.9°, 21.4°, 24.2°, 24.5°, 26.6°, 28.0°, 28.7°, 30.6°, 31.5°, 33.8°, 35.8°, 37.8°, 39.1°, 42.7°, 43.1°, and 49.3°, corresponding to the planes (110), (002), (111), (−112), (021), (200), (−022), (112), (−113), (022), (−221), (−222), (−131), (−223), (310), (132), and (−133) [32,33]. The data aligns well with the XRD diffraction peaks of Cu2V2O7 phase with CuO and V2O5 in a 2:1 molar ratio, and consistent with JCPDS Card No. 26–0569 and its C2/c space group [32]. Additionally, the XRD patterns of CuOx/VOx exhibit peaks matching Cu0.55V2O5 (JCPDS Card No. 70–2145), which has a space group of Cm (8). The peaks at 12.2°, 18.2°, 24.8°, 26.4°, 28.8°, 30.7°, and 32.9° are assigned to the (200), (002), (110), (−111), (401), (−403), and (−312) crystal planes, respectively [31]. This comprehensive analysis confirms the successful formation of CuOx/VOx. 3.2 SEM TEM and HRTEM characterization As shown in Fig. 3 , the catalyst morphology was characterized by TEM, SEM and HRTEM. The TEM images reveal a plate-like morphology (Fig. 3a, 3b). SEM further shows that the plate-like catalyst consists of irregular spherical particles stacked together, with numerous porous structures on its surface (Fig. 3c, 3d). This structure characteristics can facilitate the interaction between the substrate and the catalytic active sites, and thereby improve the catalytic efficiency. High-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) reveals the presence of four types of crystal planes (Fig. 3e–3h), specifically Cu (111), Cu2O (200), CuO (002), and Cu2V2O7 (200), with lattice spacings of 0.208 nm [34], 0.212 nm [35], 0.244 nm [36], and 0.353 nm [37], respectively. High-angle annular dark-field (HAADF) micrographs and EDS mapping images show the distribution of Cu, V, N, C, and O in CuOx/VOx (Figs. 3i–3o and S2). As shown in Fig. 3j, there is the uniform dispersion of carbon within the material. And we noted that the carbon matrix modulates the catalyst’s electronic transfer via work function reduction, which enhances intermetallic electron mobility and ultimately drives efficient base-free alcohol oxidation [38]. So the presence of carbon in this catalyst could be conducive to the conversion of alcohols to aldehydes under alkaline-free conditions. At the same time, the N atoms in the catalyst could also improve the basicity of CuOx/VOx, which lowers the alcohol dehydrogenation barrier and then subsequently promotes benzyl oxide adsorption on Cu sites [39]. Moreover, it is evident that Cu, V and N elements are uniformly distributed in the catalyst, which further support the successful introduction of Cu into the material (Fig. 3i and Table S1). 3.3 Nitrogen adsorption–desorption analysis The surface area, pore size, and pore volume of the composites were analyzed employing N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms (Fig. 4 ). The results show that both the catalyst and its precursors exhibit a type IV isotherm with an H3 type hysteresis loop, which is a characteristic of mesoporous structures [40,41]. Subsequently, the pore size distribution of V-Bpydc, Cu(NO3)2@V-Bpydc, VOx, and CuOx/VOx were examined. The findings (Table 1 ) indicate that the four samples are typical of mesoporous materials. Notably, CuOx/VOx exhibits the highest BET surface area (18 m2/g) among the three materials because of partial deligandation of the precursor [42], which is consistent with the TGA result (Fig. S3). Furthermore, compared to VOx (9.60 nm), CuOx/VOx (8.50 nm) exhibits a reduction in pore diameter, likely due to the partial blockage of pore channels by CuOx [43]. However, the pore volume of CuOx/VOx (0.069 cm3/g) significantly increases compared to the three materials (0.032 to 0.047 cm3/g), because of partial deligandation of the precursor. This alteration also facilitates the interactions between substrates and catalytic active sites, thereby promoting the progression of the reaction. 3.4 X‑ray photoelectron spectroscopy characterization To understand the chemical composition and chemical states of the elements on the material surface, XPS characterization was performed. From the wide scan spectra (Fig. 5 a), it can be observed that the catalyst contains Cu, V, O, N, and C elements. Subsequently, the spectra of the C 1 s, V 2p, O 1 s, and N 1 s regions in CuOx/VOx were measured and fitted. As display in Fig. 5b, The C 1 s spectrum can be deconvoluted into three fitted peaks located at 284.8 eV (CC), 286.50 eV (CO/CN) and 289.00 eV (O C = O). Importantly, the O C = O is derived from the ligand, which further illustrates that the CuOx/VOx is origin from the partial deligandation of Cu(NO3)2@V-Bpydc. From the Table S2, it can be found that the Cu/V, Cu/N and Cu/C atomic ratios are 0.59, 4.64 and 0.0059, respectively. It is worth mentioned that the material with high atomic ratio of C and O confirms the residual of ligand. As shown in Tables S3 and S4, the ICP-OES was carried out to confirm the content of Cu and V in the CuOx/VOx. It can be calculated that the ratio of Cu and V is 0.67, which is close to 0.59 obtained from the XPS analysis due to the high distribution of elements on the catalyst surface. In the Fig. 5c, the Cu 2p spectrum can be deconvoluted into Cu+(933.00 eV), Cu2+(934.74 eV), Cu0(936.10 eV) for Cu 2p3/2 and Cu+(952.35 eV), Cu2+(954.60 eV), Cu0 (955.40 eV) for Cu 2p1/2 [44,45]. The binding energies of 943.67 eV, 941.08 eV, and 962.08 eV are associated to satellite peaks, which illustrates the existence of unfilled 3d shells in Cu and presence of Cu2+ [31,46]. Through quantitative analysis of the fine spectrum of Cu 2p, it was found that Cu2+ is the main component of the catalyst, with the contents of Cu2+, Cu+, and Cu0 accounting for 43%, 36%, and 21%, respectively. The results from Auger spectroscopy also indicate the presence of Cu0 and Cu+in the catalyst (Fig. S5). Moreover, the Auger spectrum shows that Cu2+ is the primary component of CuOX, with the highest contribution, which aligns consistently with the Cu 2p XPS spectra results. It is crucial to emphasize that in the XPS spectrum of Cu 2p, the main peak of Cu2+ (934.74 eV) shifts toward a higher energy region compared to the main peak of pure CuO (933.55 eV), and it implies a chemical reaction between V5+ and Cu2+/Cu+, leading to the formation of Cu-O-V bonds [45]. The V 2p spectrum can be deconvoluted into four fitted peaks in Fig. 5d, with two peaks located at 517.13 eV (V 2p3/2) and 524.50 eV (V 2p1/2) corresponding to V5+ species in the sample, while the other two peaks at 515.66 eV (V 2p3/2) and 522.88 eV (V 2p1/2) are assigned to V4+ species in the catalyst. It is important to point out that the introduction of Cu contributes to a shift in the binding energy of V 2p3/2 towards a lower energy region, which is consistent with the studies performed by Seo et al. [37]. This result may suggest that the V5+/4+ ions react with Cu ions, and result in strong electronic interactions [45]. As shown in Fig. S4, the V 2p signals of the CuOx/VOx move to lower binding energy compared to the V 2p signals in VOx. The results show that the introduction of Cu species can increase the electron density of the V. It is noteworthy that the V4+/V5+ ratio in CuOx/VOx is 0.497, significantly higher than that in V2O5 (0.062) and VO2 (0.335) reported by Chen et al., and it indicates an electron transfer process from CuOx to VOx [47]. Notably, the Cu-modified VOx structure enables efficient oxygen activation through electron transfer via Cu-O-V bonds [39]. In Fig. 5e, the O 1 s signal peak could be deconvoluted into three peaks, with 530.21 eV and 532.06 eV corresponding to lattice oxygen and oxygen vacancy, respectively [48]. The peak at 533.42 eV is associated with adsorbed molecular water [31,45]. And oxygen vacancies enhance O2 adsorption on the catalyst surface, which could promote the conversion of oxygen to H2O2 [49]. The high-resolution N 1 s XPS spectrum reveals only one nitrogen species (Fig. 5f), corresponding to Cu-N at 400.39 eV [50,51]. However, the Cu-N peak shifts to a higher binding energy compared to the reported XPS results, indicating the electron delocalization from N to Cu [52]. 3.5 Raman spectroscopy characterization Raman spectra of VOx and CuOx/VOx were analyzed to compare their chemical structures and bonding properties. Interestingly, as shown in Fig. 6 b, the CuOx/VOx spectrum exhibits a characteristic peak at 893 cm⁻¹, relating to the stretching vibration of Cu-O-V bonds, which further reveals the successful synthesis of the bimetallic oxides [45,53]. Moreover, the formation of Cu-O-V bonds on the catalyst surface is likely to induce changes in the lattice structure, which could account for the significant differences observed in the XRD peaks of VOx and CuOx/VOx (Fig. 2b) [45]. Notably, the intensities of peaks in CuOx/VOx are significantly lower than those in VOx, which can be attributed to the decreased content of these bonds because of increased oxygen vacancies on the catalyst surface [54]. Importantly, compared with the VOx, the V-O peaks of CuOx/VOx has undergone a red shift, which further confirms that the introduction of Cu species increases the content of oxygen vacancies [55]. 3.6 Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy characterization The V-Bpydc, Cu(NO3)2@V-Bpydc, and CuOx/VOx were characterized by FT-IR, as shown in the Fig. 7 . In the IR spectrum, the peaks at 1633 cm⁻¹ and 1355 cm⁻¹ correspond to the antisymmetric stretching vibration of C = O groups and the bending vibration of CH bonds in Bpydc, respectively [56]. The peak at 1469 cm⁻¹ is assigned to the stretching vibration of C = C in Bpydc [40]. The presence of these three peaks in Cu(NO3)2@V-Bpydc and CuOx/VOx confirms the residual of Bpydc, which aligns with the TGA result. A comparison of the IR spectra of V-Bpydc and Cu(NO3)2@V-Bpydc reveals characteristic Cu-O peaks at 551 cm⁻¹ and 513 cm⁻¹ in the latter [32]. Additionally, the presence of Cu-O characteristic peaks in CuOx/VOx furthermore confirms the successful incorporation of Cu species. In addition, the IR spectrum of CuOx/VOx shows three peaks at 1094 cm⁻¹, 940 cm⁻¹, and 810 cm⁻¹, which relates to the V = O stretching vibration and the antisymmetric stretching vibration of V-O-V [32]. This further illustrates the presence of copper vanadate in the material. 3.7 Catalytic performance: aerobic oxidation of benzyl alcohol To evaluate the catalytic performance in the selective oxidation of alcohols, benzyl alcohol was used as the substrate for the model reaction with MeCN as a solvent and oxygen as the sole oxidant. The reaction conditions were optimized without other additives (Tables 2 and S5). Initially, various catalysts were screened, and CuOx/VOx was identified as the optimal catalyst (Table S5, Entries 1–7). Next, different solvents were evaluated. When water was used as the solvent, benzyl alcohol showed almost no conversion (Table 2 , Entry 1). Similarly, the conversions of benzyl alcohol in toluene, chlorobenzene, and DMF were unsatisfactory (14–34%) (Table 2 , Entries 2–4). These results imply that MeCN is the better solvent for this reaction. Subsequently, the reaction temperature was explored, and the temperature could be reduced to 80 °C without compromising the conversion of benzyl alcohol (Table 2 , Entries 5–7). Finally, the catalyst amount was investigated, and 4 mg was identified to be the optimal amount with 0.2 mmol benzyl alcohol (Table 2, Entries 8–9). Therefore, the optimal conditions for the selective oxidation of benzyl alcohol to benzaldehyde are summarized in Entry 8 of Table 2. 3.8 Substrate scope As shown in Scheme 1 , with the optimal conditions in hand, the substrate scope of the aerobic oxidation of alcohol was explored. And the alcohols were converted to the corresponding aldehydes with excellent selectivity (>99%). Initially, benzyl alcohol substrates with electron-donating group on the aromatic ring were studied, yielding the corresponding target products (2b-2f) in good to excellent conversion (88%−99%). Notably, when the methyl group was positioned at the ortho (2b, 93%) or meta positions on benzene ring (2c, 89%), the conversions were lower than that at the para position (2d, 99%), likely due to steric hindrance. Different halogens located at the para positions on an aromatic ring were explored, and the corresponding aldehydes can be obtained with excellent conversions of 97%−99% (2 g-2i). Additionally, when a nitro group was located at the para position, the target product can be obtained quantitatively (2j). Even an additional phenyl ring was introduced at the para position of the parent substrate, the 4-biphenylmethanol can be transformed into the corresponding 4-biphenylcarbaldehyde (2k) with a conversion of 95%. Encouraged by these results, substrates with conjugated systems were also investigated. The corresponding alcohols provided the desired products (2l-2n) in good conversions (81%−92%). To evaluate the functional group tolerance of this catalytic system, alcohol derivatives containing heterocycles were further examined. The results show its effectiveness for both six-membered heterocycles (1o) and five-membered heterocycles (1p-1q). Finally, the applicability of the catalytic system to other primary and secondary alcohols was explored. Both allylic alcohols (1r-1s) and secondary alcohols (1t) afforded the corresponding products in excellent conversions (99%). 3.9 Gram-scale amplification reaction, heterogeneity and stability of catalysts To assess the practical application potential of the catalytic system, a gram-scale reaction was performed using 10 mmol of benzyl alcohol (1a) under the optimal conditions (Scheme 2 ). Benzaldehyde was obtained in 81% conversion, which indicates that CuOx/VOx possesses the practical application potential. The heterogeneity of the catalytic system was confirmed through the leaching experiment (Fig. 8 a). The stability and reusability of catalyst are of great significance in practical applications. Recycling experiment results of CuOx/VOx in Fig. 8b confirm that the catalyst shows no significant loss of catalytic activity after five cycles, which indicate the good stability of catalyst. 3.10 Mechanism experiments A series of control experiments were carried out to explore the catalytic oxidation mechanism of benzyl alcohol with CuOx/VOx. The results in Scheme 3 a and 3b confirmed that both the catalyst and oxygen are key factors for the progress of the reaction. Oxygen vacancy scavengers (KI and NaHCO₃) were introduced into the reaction system (Scheme 3c and 3d), and the reactions were almost complete blocked. It indicates that oxygen vacancies on the surface of catalyst are vital for this catalytic reaction [57]. The KMnO4 redox decolorization experiment [58] and N, N‑diethyl-p-phenylenediamine/horseradish peroxidase method [59] indicate the formation of H2O2 in the reaction system (Scheme 3e and Fig. S6).The addition of TEMPO (2,2,6,6-tetramethylpiperidine-N-oxyl) as a radical scavenger under standard conditions (Scheme 3f) confirms the involvement of hydroxyl radicals (•OH) in the catalytic reaction. As shown in Fig. 9 , BQ (p-benzoquinone), FOL (furfuryl alcohol), and mannitol were used as scavengers for superoxide radicals (•O2−), singlet oxygen (1O2), and •OH, respectively [40,41,60,61]. The findings further verify the significance of •OH in this reaction. As shown in Scheme 3g and 3h, neither target products nor •OH was observed in the reaction of benzyl alcohol with H2O2, which indicates that •OH is not generated through the thermal decomposition of H2O2. Under the same conditions, the results of the reactions with VOx, CuO, Cu2O, and Cu as catalysts (Scheme 3i–3l) suggest that H2O2 primarily undergoes homolytic cleavage on CuO sites to generate •OH. And then, the roles of N species and Cu-O-V bonds in enhancement of catalytic performance were also confirmed. As seen in Entry 1 of Table 3 , CuOx/VOx (H2Bpdc) (see supporting information for preparation process) was selected as a catalyst, and the result revealed the essential role of N species, and it can be attributed to their electron-donating capability. Subsequent experiments examining the synergistic effect of CuOx/VOx (Table 3 , Entries 2–6) and physical mixtures of VOx with CuO, Cu2O, and Cu (Table 3 , Entries 7–10) indicate that the catalytic performance enhancement originates from the synergistic interaction between CuOX and VOX through Cu-O-V bond. Based on the above experiments and previous works [49,59,62–64], a possible mechanism of the reaction was proposed in Scheme 4 . Firstly, oxygen is adsorbed on oxygen vacancies on the surface of catalyst to generate adsorbed oxygen, which is then activated to form A by accepting electron from the Cu species through Cu-O-V bond (I to II) [65,66]. And then B is generated after the deprotonation of 1a under the action of the catalyst. Subsequently, C is obtained by capturing the released proton (II to III). Next, the α-carbon CH bond is broken by the reaction with C to furnish H2O2 and 1b, and the catalyst is regenerated (III to IV). Then, the obtained H2O2 can undergo the homolytic cleavage to produce the •OH at CuOx sites (Scheme 3j), and •OH can react with B to produce H2O and 1b [67] with the regeneration of the catalyst (IV to VI). As summarized in Table 4 , the catalytic performance of CuOx/VOx compares favorably with reported systems for the selective oxidation of alcohols. Some existing systems require TEMPO or base as additives, which increase both reaction costs and post-processing complexity (Entry 1–4). Although some systems do not require additives, the high temperature or pressure (Entry 5–8) and specialized conditions (Entry 9) are still the main limitations that restrict the application of the catalytic systems. The catalytic oxidation of alcohols with CuOx/VOx as a catalyst could be achieved under simple conditions, and this catalytic system represents a more economical and practical approach for the aerobic oxidation of alcohols (Entry 10). 4 Conclusion In summary, CuOx/VOx synthesized through the partial deligandation of Cu(NO3)2@V-Bpydc enables the efficient oxidation of alcohols to aldehydes using oxygen as the sole oxidant under additive-free conditions. XRD, SEM, XPS, Raman, and BET characterizations were conducted to establish the relationship between the catalyst structure and its catalytic performance. The results show that CuOx/VOx features abundant mesoporous structures and increased BET surface area after the partial deligandation of amorphous MOFs material, which are essential for the mass transfer of substrates and products. And the electron transfer via Cu-O-V bonds boosts the process of exchange between lattice oxygen and absorbed oxygen. Moreover, the catalyst with rich oxygen vacancies facilitates oxygen adsorption and the generation of H2O2 in situ. The related mechanistic studies reveal that the synergistic effect between CuOX and VOX via Cu-O-V bonds is critical for the catalytic performance. Notably, the dual role of N species in the catalyst, as an electron donor and the enhancement of the catalyst's basicity, also improves the catalytic performance. Importantly, CuOx/VOx possesses excellent stability, exhibiting no significant activity loss after five cycles. This catalytic system provides valuable insights to strategies for design aMOFs-based catalysts for the selective aerobic oxidation of alcohols to aldehydes without extra additives under mild conditions. coredata.dc:description: The selective oxidation of alcohols to aldehydes using oxygen as the sole oxidant under mild conditions presents a scientifically challenging task. Here, the bimetallic CuOx/VOx composite as a heterogenous catalyst was synthesized through the partial deligandation of amorphous MOFs (aMOFs) for the selective oxidation of alcohols to aldehydes with base-free condition with molecular oxygen as the oxidant at 80 °C. The catalyst was characterized by XRD, TEM, SEM, HRTEM, BET, XPS, Raman, and FTIR spectroscopy. The characteristic results and mechanism experiments reveal that the synergistic effect between CuOX and VOX via Cu-O-V bonds and the presence of abundant oxygen vacancies on the surface of the material are crucial for the efficient catalytic oxidation of the alcohols. Importantly, the role of nitrogen atoms in the catalyst, both as an electron-donor and a basicity-enhancer, significantly improves the catalytic performance of CuOx/VOx. Mechanistic studies indicate that the reaction primarily involves a free radical process and the formation of H2O2 in situ. The catalytic system exhibits a broad substrate scope and excellent selectivity. The catalyst recycling experiments show that its catalytic performance remained robust, with no significant loss in the catalytic activity observed.
